Get all versions, for all regulations.

cache_root_and_interps(reg_tree, version, is_root=True)[source]¶

We will re-use the root tree at multiple points during page rendering, so cache it now. If caching an interpretation, also store child interpretations with titles (so that, when rendering slide-down interpretations, we don’t perform additional fetches)

regulations.generator.notices.filter_labeled_children(sxs)[source]¶

Some children don’t have labels. We display those with their parents. The other children are displayed when they are independently, specifically requested.

regulations.generator.notices.find_label_in_sxs(sxs_list, label_id, fr_page=None)[source]¶

Given a tree of SXS sections, find a non-empty sxs that matches label_id. Some notices may have the same label appearing multiple times; use fr_page to distinguish, defaulting to the first

regulations.generator.section_url module¶

class regulations.generator.section_url.SectionUrl[source]¶

Bases: object

With few exceptions, users are expected to browse the regulation by traversing regtext sections, appendices, and subterps (split interpretations). This object will deduce, from a version and citation, to which section/appendix/subterp to link, a task greatly complicated by subterps. Importantly, this object keeps a cache of looked up info; reusing an instance is significantly faster than using static methods.

fetch(citation, version, sectional)[source]¶
interp(citation, version)[source]¶

Subterps throw a big monkey-wrench into things. Citations to interpretations must be converted into their corresponding subterp, which requires loading the toc.

static of(citation, version, sectional)[source]¶
view_label_id(citation, version)[source]¶

regulations.generator.subterp module¶

regulations.generator.subterp.filter_by_subterp(nodes, subterp_label, version)[source]¶

Given an interp node (e.g. a node with label [‘1005’, ‘Interp’]), remove all irrelevant sub-nodes. Note that stripping out nodes is more efficient than compiling nodes when API calls are involved. We use takewhile and dropwhile in case extra, non-node interpretations are in the range

Utility method for splitting a string by one of multiple chars

regulations.generator.toc module¶

The table of contents needed isn’t quite the same as the toc provided by the api. We need to modify it a bit to group subparts, subterps, etc. These modifications, then, are used for navigation, citations, and the TOC layer

regulations.generator.toc.fetch_toc(reg_part, version, flatten=False)[source]¶

Fetch the toc, transform it into a list usable by navigation, etc.

regulations.generator.toc.intro_interps(toc, reg_part)[source]¶

Logic to fill in any introduction headers for the entire interpretations. Note that at some point, we might have headers randomly appear elsewhere in the interpretations, unrelated to a specific section. That’s a @todo.

regulations.generator.toc.subterps(so_far, reg_part)[source]¶

Logic to build subterps, collections of interpretations for subparts, the empty subpart, or appendices

regulations.generator.toc.toc_interp(data, so_far, toc)[source]¶

Transforms a subpart, expanding it into subterps (collections of interpreted subparts, empty part, and appendices

regulations.generator.toc.toc_sect_appendix(data, so_far)[source]¶

Transforms normal sections and appendices

regulations.generator.toc.toc_subpart(data, so_far, toc)[source]¶

Transforms a subpart, giving it sectional children
